NEVER HAVE TO BOTHER ABOUT STARTING
THIS FIRE IT'S BEEN BURNING 200 YEARS
Cumberland, England, July 9. "I
can't remember when the kitchen
fire has ever gone out. There has
always been a fire in it ever since I
can remember, and I'm 39 years old.
My father, who lived to '75, told me
he could never remember the time
when the kitchen fire wasn't aglow,
and he also told me that his father
never saw a cold grate in the kitchen.
The family history says that the fire.

ON FEBRUARY THE 15th WE HAD A BAD FIRE IN OUR STORE, CAUSING
a large loss to our grocery and dry goods departments. The fire was confined to the
Grocery department, but we experienced a severe loss from smoke in the other department, and have made up our mind to close
out the entire stock. This is our reason for putting on the greatest merchandise sale ever held in Jamestown. We are offering to
the public our entire line of dry goods, consisting of ladies ready-to-wear garments, wash goods, hosiery, underwear, shoes, notions,
etc., staple and fancy groceries. In fact everything in our store must go in the next two weeks regardless of cost. $60,000 worth of
merchandise must be sold in this short space of time. This includes thousands of dollars worth of new spring goods, such as ladies
suits, coats, skirts, wash goods, embroideries, laces and articles too numerous to mention.
EVERYBODY IS TALKING ABOUT THIS GREAT SALE
People from far and wide are planning to attend. Our sales force will be greatly increased and we are going to try and wait on and please
everyone to the best of our ability. We are going over our stock carefully and are considering the conditions of the same in
prices. Space will not permit us to quote prices on every line of goods but we give below prices on just a few of the many bargains we have to offer
SALE COMMENCES

LASTS TWO WEEKS

258
THE INDIAN ADVOCATE
:f.
a quarter of a mile north of the school a black swath, two
miles wide, stretched eastward as far as the eye could
reach; at its end a red streak of fire was visible.
Knowing that there would be no more study until her
pupils had satisfied their curiosity about the fire, Maura
rang the recess bell.
The fire excited the teacher quite as much as it did her
pupils. She was, as yet, a novice in the teaching profes
sion, and it was her first year on the Llano Estacado, so
this was the first prairie fire she had seen, though she had
heard of the dreaded prairie fires that caused great
damage, destroying the grass, the only sustenance of the
great herds of cattle that roamed its vast expanse.
There was much surmising among the children as to how
the fire got out, where it would end, the fire guards it
would jump, and much more to the same effect.
Roy Smith volunteered the information, "Teacher, the
fire started at Mr. Gaines'es, I seen it through the window
when it first got out. 'Taint been more'n ten minutes ago,
Mrs. Gaines was washing and a spark blew from under the
wash pot and set the grass."
For once Roy's grammar went uncorrected.
Now, men on horseback rode swiftly past the school in
the direction of the fire. It is the custom on the plains,
when a fire is seen, for everyone that lives within sight
of it to go and assist in extinguishing it; this being the
case, fires are often checked before they have done great
damage.
Today, the task of extinguishing the fire would be no
easy one, as a stiff breeze was blowing, and under such
conditions fire guards or ploughed furrows around the
fences would prove ineffectual in stopping it, as the wind
was strong enough to blow the sparks a distance of sever
al yards.
As Maura stood in the yard with her pupils, watching
the onward rush of the fire, she noticed a tiny patch of
fire on the edge of the burned patch nearest the school.
"It's broke out fresh," exclained Jim West, one of the
oldest pupils, a boy of sixteen.

With a well-trained crew of volunteers, completely equipped fire trucks and an ambulance and rescue squad,
the residents of Wibaux and Wibaux county are assured of good fire protection. Standing by the rural fire
truck is Charles Jewett, chief of the Wibaux fire and rescue squad. (MF-S photo)
SOMETIME AGO the Wibaux rural vol
unteer fire department answered a call to a
farm home 25 miles away. They had water
on the fire within 30 minutes after receiving
the call. While they were unable to save the
home, the fire was kept from spreading to
the farmer's hay supply and other buildings.
Shortly afterward another call was an
swered to a farm 26 miles from Wibaux. A
propane-fed fire was raging in the basement.
The volunteers were on the scene within 35
minutes and confined the damage to the
basements, joists and sub-flooring.
Can a rural fire fighting unit stationed
at a central location give protection to farms
many miles away? The folks in Wibaux
county have had convincing proof that it
can.
Rural Department
The Wibaux rural fire department has
been in service since 1953 and is an out
growth of the volunteer department in the
town of Wibaux. Prior to 1949 Wibaux's fire
fighting equipment consisted of four hand
drawn hose carts of pre-World War I vin
tage and some chemical tanks. Insurance
rates in the town were based on "no fire
protection."
Wibaux's present volunteer fire depart
ment was organized in 1948. The purchase
of a new fire truck was authorized and they
received delivery on it in May of 1949.
A short time later Wibaux experienced
an elevator fire, the worst fire disaster in
the history of the town. The volunteers were
unable to control the blaze, but if it hadn't
been for the new equipment and trained
men to operate it, the fire would have
spread to the REA pole yard where $7,000
worth of poles were stored, a gasoline bulk
station and the town's coal shed.
Out-of-Town Fires
Whether Wibaux county began to ex
perience more fires than usual, or fires that
normally would have gone unnoticed before
were being brought to attention through the
volunteer fire department, is unknown. But
the Wibaux volunteers were being called to
assist with many fires outside the town.
Since insurance on the fire truck is invalid
COVERS MONTANA AND NORTHERN WYOMING
outside the city limits, the truck could not
go to these fires. The volunteers would load
what equipment they could on pickups and
go out and fight the blaze.
The need for a truck for rural fire pro
tection in the county soon became apparent
and, with donations and help from the
County Commissioners, volunteer fire fight
ers and the Rural Fire Wardens, a truck
was bought to be used exclusively for rural
fire protection.
Fully Equipped
It's equipped with a 500-gallon water
tank, 250 gallon-per-minute high pressure
pump, two high pressure booster hoses with
250 feet on each reel, 500 feet of IVa-inch
hose, fire beaters for grass fires, fog nozzles,
ax, bar, ladder, five 5-gallon back packs,
shovels, litter carrier, rescue rope and two
smoke masks.
The cost of such a unit would normally
run around $10,000, according to Charles
Jewett, chief of the Wibaux Fire and Rescue
Squad. By buying the truck chassis, having
the body built to their own specifications at
a local body shop and by buying the equip
ment separately, Wibaux county was able to
get its truck for $6,500.
There are 24 volunteers on the Wibaux
Fire Department. Ten men go with the rural
truck when answering calls in the county «
and the rest remain in town to man the city
truck, should a fire break out. They meet
once a month for training sessions and prac
tice drills in the use of the equipment.
Teamwork
Just as teamwork is an important factor
in efficient use of fire fighting equipment,
cooperation between other rural fire de
partments has shown its value in providing
rural fire protection. The roof of a two
story farm house was struck by lightning
during a freak storm last March.
Jewett says the house was equipped with
properly installed lightning rods, but the
ground was too dry to ground the lightning.
It knocked out the entire electrical system
of the house, followed the service wires to
a pole and disin- (continued on page 6)
